transitHacks.title: Suica/Pasmo
transitHacks.description: Get a rechargeable IC card at any station. Works on trains, buses, and many convenience stores. Tap in and out—no need to buy single tickets.

transitHacks.title: Rush-hour gaps
transitHacks.description: Avoid the Yamanote Line 7–9am and 5–7pm. Use the Chuo or Sobu lines for slightly less crowding, or travel just before/after peaks.

transitHacks.title: Quiet carriages
transitHacks.description: Many lines have "women-only" cars during rush hours (marked on the platform). General riders should avoid phone calls and loud conversations in all cars.

localEtiquette.title: Train manners
localEtiquette.description: Keep bags on your lap or in overhead racks. Don't eat or drink on most trains. Priority seats are for elderly, pregnant, and disabled passengers.
do: Stand on the left on escalators (Tokyo)
dont: Eat or drink on local trains

localEtiquette.title: Tipping
localEtiquette.description: Tipping is not customary in Japan. It can even cause confusion. Excellent service is the norm without extra payment.

transitHacks.title: Navigo Découverte
transitHacks.description: Weekly pass (Mon–Sun) for zones 1–5. Bring a photo; you'll need it to validate the pass. Cheaper than daily tickets if you're staying 4+ days.

transitHacks.title: RATP app
transitHacks.description: Use the official RATP app for real-time Métro, RER, and bus info. Offline maps available—download before you go.

transitHacks.title: Avoid strike days
transitHacks.description: Check for grèves (strikes) on RATP or SNCF. On strike days, expect reduced service; have backup plans (walking, Bolt, etc.).

localEtiquette.title: Greetings
localEtiquette.description: Always say "Bonjour" when entering a shop or café. "Bonsoir" after dark. Skipping it is considered rude.
dont: Eat while walking in nice areas

localEtiquette.title: Dining
localEtiquette.description: Meals are leisurely. Don't ask for the check too quickly—it can feel like you're being rushed out.
do: Keep hands on the table (wrists visible)
dont: Order café au lait with dinner

transitHacks.title: Rabbit Card
transitHacks.description: The Rabbit Card (BTS) and MRT equivalents work across BTS Skytrain, MRT, BRT, and many retailers. Top up at stations or 7-Eleven. Cheaper than single tickets and avoids queue chaos.

transitHacks.title: BTS vs MRT vs river
transitHacks.description: BTS (elevated) and MRT (underground) use different ticketing. For 2026, consider a stored-value card for each if you use both often. River ferries and express boats are cheap and skip traffic—ideal for Old City and riverside areas.

transitHacks.title: Grab / Bolt
transitHacks.description: Use Grab or Bolt for motorbike taxis and cars. Cheaper than hailed cabs; fix fares upfront. Avoid tuk-tuks for medium-long trips unless you agree a price first.

localEtiquette.title: Respect for the King and religion
localEtiquette.description: Criticism of the monarchy is illegal. Don't step on or disrespect Thai currency (it bears the King's image). Dress modestly at temples and the Grand Palace.
do: Stand for the royal anthem in cinemas
Remove shoes before entering temples and homes
dont: Point feet at people or Buddha images

localEtiquette.title: Temples and sacred sites
localEtiquette.description: Shoulders and knees must be covered. No shorts, sleeveless tops, or short skirts. Rent wraps at major sites if needed.

transitHacks.title: Contactless / Oyster
transitHacks.description: Use contactless debit/credit or Oyster. Same daily and weekly caps. No need to buy a separate Oyster if your card works. Tap in and out on Tube and rail.

transitHacks.title: Phone snatching (2026)
transitHacks.description: Moped and bike phone snatching remains common, especially near stations and at lights. Keep phones out of reach; avoid scrolling while walking at the curb. Use inside pockets or a cross-body bag.

transitHacks.title: Elizabeth Line & off-peak
transitHacks.description: Elizabeth Line connects Heathrow, central London, and beyond. Use off-peak where possible—fares are cheaper. Rail strikes still occur; check National Rail / TfL for disruptions.

localEtiquette.title: Queuing and Tube etiquette
localEtiquette.description: Brits take queueing seriously. Don't push or skip. On escalators, stand on the right, walk on the left. Let people off the Tube before boarding.
do: Give up seats for those who need them
dont: Eat smelly food on the Tube
Spread bags on seats at peak

localEtiquette.title: Pubs and tipping
localEtiquette.description: Order (and often pay) at the bar. Tipping isn't expected but rounding up or 10% is appreciated. Don't gesture with your index finger; it can be seen as rude.
do: Wait your turn at the bar

transitHacks.title: Nol Card tiers
transitHacks.description: Silver (pay-as-you-go), Gold (premium Metro cabins), Red (tourist day passes). Silver is best for most visitors; top up at stations or authorised outlets. Works on Metro, Tram, buses, and water ferries.

transitHacks.title: Metro cabin rules
transitHacks.description: Gold Class and Women & Children cabins have clear signage. Don't use them unless eligible. Fines for eating, drinking, or inappropriate behaviour on Metro.

transitHacks.title: Careem / Uber vs taxis
transitHacks.description: RTA taxis are metered and reliable. Careem and Uber also operate. Surge pricing is common during peak. For short hops, Nol on buses or Tram can be cheaper.

localEtiquette.title: Dress and public behaviour
localEtiquette.description: Dress modestly in public areas—shoulders and knees covered in malls and government buildings. PDA is frowned upon. No public drunkenness; alcohol only in licensed venues.
do: Respect Ramadan (no eating/drinking in public during daylight)
Use right hand for handshakes and giving

localEtiquette.title: Hotels and licensed venues
localEtiquette.description: Alcohol is served only in licensed hotels and bars. Don't carry open alcohol in public. Drink responsibly; drunk behaviour can lead to arrest.
do: Be respectful in mosques (non-Muslims at designated times only)
dont: Bring pork or inappropriate materials into UAE

transitHacks.title: Istanbulkart
transitHacks.description: Reloadable Istanbulkart works on Metro, tram, funicular, ferry, and buses. Buy at machines or kiosks; one card can serve several people (tap per person). Much cheaper than single tickets.

transitHacks.title: Ferries and traffic
transitHacks.description: Traffic is heavy. Use ferries for cross-Bosphorus and Princes' Islands—scenic and often faster. Marmaray links Asian and European sides underground.

transitHacks.title: Tram to Sultanahmet
transitHacks.description: T1 tram serves Sultanahmet, Grand Bazaar, and Galata. Crowded; watch wallets and phones. Validate at platform readers.

localEtiquette.title: Mosque dress codes
localEtiquette.description: Shoulders and knees must be covered; women cover hair. Many mosques provide loan scarves and wraps. Remove shoes; carry them in bags provided. Don't visit during prayer times if you're only touring.

localEtiquette.title: Bazaars and haggling
localEtiquette.description: Haggling is expected in bazaars. Be polite but firm. A smile and "Hayır, teşekkürler" (No, thank you) go far. Don't feel obliged to buy after tea.
do: Check prices at a few stalls first
dont: Be aggressive or rude when declining
Touch items you don't intend to buy

transitHacks.title: EZ-Link / NETS FlashPay
transitHacks.description: Use EZ-Link or NETS FlashPay for MRT, LRT, and buses. Tap in and out. Same card can pay at some retail and F&B. Tourist passes available for unlimited travel over 1–3 days.

transitHacks.title: MRT rules and fines
transitHacks.description: No eating, drinking, or smoking. No durian. Penalties are stiff. MRT is clean, safe, and efficient; avoid peak 8–9am and 5–7pm if possible.

transitHacks.title: Grab and taxis
transitHacks.description: Grab and Gojek operate. Taxis use meters; surcharges apply at certain times and zones. Ride-hail often similar price; use either.

localEtiquette.title: Backpack rules on MRT
localEtiquette.description: Take your backpack off on crowded MRT and buses—hold it in front or put it on the floor. Reduces bumping and saves space. "Priority" seats are for those who need them.
dont: Eat or drink on public transport

localEtiquette.title: Littering and gum
localEtiquette.description: Heavy fines for littering, spitting, and chewing gum. Use bins. Don't jaywalk; use crossings. Laws are strictly enforced.
dont: Smoke indoors or in non-designated areas

transitHacks.title: OMNY or MetroCard
transitHacks.description: OMNY (contactless card or phone) or MetroCard for Subway and buses. OMNY has daily and weekly fare caps. MetroCard is being phased out; OMNY preferred for 2026.

transitHacks.title: Subway tips
transitHacks.description: Check MTA app or maps for service changes. Express vs local trains—know your stops. Avoid empty cars at night; they're often empty for a reason. Keep bags and phones secure.

transitHacks.title: Citi Bike and ferries
transitHacks.description: Citi Bike for short hops; Lyft Pink etc. can include passes. Ferry to Staten Island is free; other routes (e.g. East River) are cheap and scenic.

localEtiquette.title: Subway and sidewalk
localEtiquette.description: Move to the centre of the car; don't block doors. Let people off before boarding. On sidewalks, walk on the right; don't stop abruptly in the middle of flow.
dont: Eat smelly food on the train
Stand in the way of doors

localEtiquette.title: Tipping
localEtiquette.description: Tipping is expected: ~15–20% restaurants, a few dollars for bartenders, $1–2 per bag for porters, ~15–20% cabs/ride-hail.
dont: Assume table service at counter spots

transitHacks.title: Octopus card
transitHacks.description: Octopus works on MTR, buses, trams, ferries, and many shops. Add value at MTR or convenience stores. Optional tourist Octopus with souvenir designs.

transitHacks.title: MTR and peak hours
transitHacks.description: MTR is fast and frequent. Avoid 8–9am and 6–7pm if possible. Airport Express and Tung Chung line serve the airport. Clear signage in English.

transitHacks.title: Star Ferry and trams
transitHacks.description: Star Ferry (Central–Tsim Sha Tsui) is cheap and scenic. Ding-ding trams on HK Island are iconic; board at the back, pay when leaving front.

localEtiquette.title: Queuing and personal space
localEtiquette.description: Queue properly for transport and entries. Don't push. Personal space is limited in crowds; avoid spreading bags or blocking flow.
do: Offer seats to elderly or pregnant

localEtiquette.title: Dining and chopsticks
localEtiquette.description: Don't stick chopsticks upright in rice; it evokes incense for the dead. Don't tap bowls with chopsticks. Tea pouring is a gesture of respect; reciprocate or thank.
do: Accept tea with two fingers tap

transitHacks.title: T-money card
transitHacks.description: T-money works on Metro, buses, taxis, and many convenience stores. Buy at stations or CU/GS25. Refund unused balance (minus fee) at machines before leaving.

transitHacks.title: Subway etiquette
transitHacks.description: Reserved seats (pink/silver) are for elderly, pregnant, and disabled. Don't use them otherwise. No eating on trains; keep volume down. Lines run late; useful for evening outings.

transitHacks.title: Airport rail and Kakao T
transitHacks.description: AREX links Incheon/Gimpo to Seoul. Kakao T is the main ride-hail app; have a local number or WiFi. Taxis rank outside stations; Uber operates but Kakao T is more common.

localEtiquette.title: Respect and hierarchy
localEtiquette.description: Use two hands when giving or receiving (e.g. money, cards). Bow slightly when greeting. Don't pour your own drink; pour for others and they'll reciprocate.
do: Let elders eat or start first
dont: Blow your nose loudly at the table

localEtiquette.title: Dining and drinking
localEtiquette.description: Wait for the eldest to start. Turn away when drinking soju with elders. Don't refuse first pour; take a sip. Tipping is not customary.
do: Use both hands when holding glass for a pour
